benefitSection.title: Who Can Benefit from Foundation Year Courses?
benefitSection.intro: Foundation Year courses are an excellent opportunity for those who wish to study in the UK but do not have the academic qualifications necessary to enter directly into an undergraduate degree.

studentsLimited.title: Students with Limited Academic Experience
studentsLimited.content: If you don't have the qualifications needed to directly enter an undergraduate course, a Foundation Year offers you the chance to update your knowledge and skills for a smooth transition to higher education.

professionals.title: Professionals Returning to Academics
professionals.content: If you've been out of formal education for a while and wish to re-enter the academic environment, the Foundation Year provides preparatory support.

international.title: International Students and Immigrants
international.content: For those who have recently moved to the UK and need a year of adaptation before starting their undergraduate degree.

nonTraditional.title: Students with Non-traditional Qualifications
nonTraditional.content: If you have diplomas or qualifications that aren't directly recognized in the UK, the Foundation Year could be the bridge to your desired degree.

whatIsSection.title: What is a Foundation Year?
whatIsSection.paragraph1: The Foundation Year is a preparatory year designed to equip students with the academic skills necessary to enter a full undergraduate course.
whatIsSection.paragraph2: During this year, students receive training in subjects like mathematics, academic English, and other essential knowledge relevant to their chosen degree.
whatIsSection.paragraph3: By the end of the year, you will be ready to begin your full degree course with a solid foundation for success.

q1.question: What is Student Finance?
q1.answer: It's a UK government loan that covers the cost of university tuition fees.

q2.question: Who can apply for Student Finance?
q2.answer: British or EU citizens with pre-settled or settled status in the UK.

q3.question: Can I apply with pre-settled status?
q3.answer: Yes, if you meet the residency requirements.

q4.question: What is the difference between pre-settled and settled?
q4.answer: Pre-settled is temporary (5 years), settled is permanent. Both can qualify you depending on residency.

q5.question: What is a Foundation Year?
q5.answer: A preparatory year before starting a degree, to improve academic skills and English level.

q6.question: Do I have to pay anything during the course?
q6.answer: No. Repayment starts only after graduation and when earning above a certain threshold.

q7.question: Which universities accept Student Finance?
q7.answer: Most public universities in the UK accept it.

q8.question: How much does Student Finance cover?
q8.answer: Up to £9,250 per year for tuition fees.

q9.question: Can I get help with living costs?
q9.answer: Yes, through the Maintenance Loan if you live away from your family.

q10.question: How do I apply for Student Finance?
q10.answer: You apply online on the Student Finance England website. You can also get help from an advisor.

q11.question: What documents are needed?
q11.answer: Passport, pre/settled status, proof of address, and academic transcripts.

q12.question: How long does approval take?
q12.answer: Usually 4 to 8 weeks after submitting all documents.

q13.question: Can I choose any course?
q13.answer: Yes, as long as it's eligible and approved by Student Finance.

q14.question: Can I study part-time?
q14.answer: Yes, part-time students can also receive funding.

q15.question: My English isn't great. Can I still apply?
q15.answer: Yes, many universities offer Foundation Year with English support.

q16.question: I'm over 30. Can I still study?
q16.answer: Yes! There is no age limit for undergraduate courses with Student Finance.

q17.question: Does it cover online courses?
q17.answer: Usually not. Student Finance mainly covers in-person courses.

q18.question: What if I drop out?
q18.answer: Inform the university and Student Finance. You may have to repay for the time attended.

q19.question: What happens if I leave the UK?
q19.answer: You may still need to repay based on your income abroad.

q20.question: Are there interest rates?
q20.answer: Yes, but rates depend on your income after graduation. They are fair and income-based.

q21.question: Do I need a visa to study with Student Finance?
q21.answer: Not if you have pre-settled or settled status. Otherwise, a student visa is required.

q22.question: What is UCAS?
q22.answer: It's the official UK university application system. Most courses use it.

q23.question: Is Student Finance a loan or a scholarship?
q23.answer: It's a government loan that is repaid through taxes after graduation, only if you earn enough.

q24.question: What is student life like in the UK?
q24.answer: It's culturally rich, with great student support, events, discounts, and facilities.
